title: What is Peter optimizing for with his exercise?
content: Peter is looking at exercise through the lens of longevity, not performance. The difference is important. Longevity is a very difficult performance goal. Training for this type of performance is generally not collinear with longevity and at times they can be outright orthogonal. Exceptional physical performances requires maximum cardiac output, just beneath VO2 max. This level of performance and training puts an amazing strain on the body. While this is better than sitting on the couch all day, it is past the point of optimizing longevity returns. This comes at some longevity cost relative to training at a lower energy system.

title: Why training for the “Centenarian Decathlon” is so important
content: This podcast is geared toward this “Centenarian Decathlon”. By training in zone 2 and zone 5 (with much more focus on zone 2), we’re preparing metabolically and structurally for longevity. Preparing for a good life at age 100: Training for the “Centenarian Decathlon”. What does Peter wish he incorporated into his exercise at age 25 to be in this race for the gold medal in the “Centenarian Decathlon”? For most people, the decline of mind and body, and the burden of disease occurs as the body fails first. This prompted Peter to think about how to mitigate the decline / fail of the body.

title: Backcasting to Determine Physical Goals
content: Peter engaged in backcasting to determine what he wants to do when he is 100 and work backwards from that to determine what to do today at age 45. He realized at this age, his grandkids will have kids. When Peter is 100, he will likely have great-grandchildren that are between the ages of 1-8. He made a list of 18 things‒ this became his centenarian decathlon (even though a decathlon is only 10 things).

title: Physical Tasks for Daily Living at Age 100
content: Peter asked‒ What are physical tasks that will approximate the things he wants to be able to do for daily living at age 100? He made a list of 18 things‒ this became his centenarian decathlon (even though a decathlon is only 10 things). Activities of daily living are important. Things he would want to do with his great-grandkids when they are 1, 3, 4, 5, etc. He wants to retain his cognitive faculties. There are lots of physical activities he wants to be able to do.

title: Exercises for Longevity
content: Peter’s framework for thinking about exercise for longevity has 4 components: Stability, Strength, Aerobic performance, and Anaerobic output. Each of his 18 goals (for his Centenarian decathlon) touch on at least 1 of these items in this framework; some touch on more than 1. The goblet squat requires both strength and stability. Walking up 3 flights of stairs with 10 lbs of groceries in each hand is on the threshold of aerobic/ anaerobic output and also requires strength.

title: Importance of Stability
content: Stability is where most people first begin to fail. This begins around the time that children start school. By the time we are about 1.5-years-old, we do them all perfectly. Then it’s basically all downhill from there. Decline of stability is accelerated by school, once you start sitting. We lose the ability to maintain tension through our pelvic floor and throughout our entire core.

title: Recommendations for Stability
content: Peter recommends spending as much time as possible working on static stability then dynamic stability. Incorporate these principles into what you are doing strength-wise. At the age of 25, you can do a lot of exercises incorrectly and get away with it. But correct form is very important in the long run. Peter thinks he’s always squatted and deadlift somewhat incorrectly. He’s never fully engaged his pelvic floor doing those.

title: Breathing Squat Routine
content: Peter describes a breathing squat routine he did in high school where he lifted 6 days a week, 3 hours a day. Once a week they did a routine of breathing squats. This set takes 10 minutes. Over the course of 1 year doing this, he added over 100 lbs to his squat.

title: Super Slow Training
content: Peter talks about 'super slow' or slow training, lifting slow and accumulating time under tension ~90 seconds. Until you time yourself lifting, you don’t realize how little time is spent under tension. 90 seconds feels like an eternity.

title: Importance of Preserving Strength and Muscle Mass as We Age
content: Peter discusses the importance of preserving strength and muscle mass as we age. The lowest rate of decline in lean mass (shown by studies) is 1-2% per year after age 50; see the table below. Between ages 20-80, this is a loss of 35-40%. The strength decline may be even greater.

title: Leg Strength and Mortality
content: The change in men’s leg strength is not subtle. For every 0.2 unit reduction in strength per ct area they saw a significant increase in mortality. Strength was normalized for muscle size. Muscle area was measured by computed tomography (CT) scan, to look at cross-sectional area. Lean tissue mass was determined using DEXA (dual energy-x-ray absorptiometry). When muscle area was measured by DEXA, a 0.2 reduction in strength was associated with a 39% increase in mortality. Grip strength was normalized by a DEXA arm measurement. Reduced grip strength was associated with a 23% increase in mortality.

title: The Value of Deadlifts for Stability and Longevity
content: Peter Attia finds deadlifts to be a great total hip hinge, compound movement. He deadlifts at least twice a week (often 3x a week), both straight bar and trap bar; he doesn’t go that heavy. In terms of weight for deadlifts, Peter might have had 400 lbs on the trap bar in the past year. He usually stops at 350-375 on the trap bar. On the straight bar he goes lighter, maybe 185 lbs. His typical workout is 4-5 sets of 10 reps. He can push himself harder in other things. Peter’s goal is to do the deadlift perfectly, and he is constantly checking his form.

title: Preparing for Deadlifts
content: Peter Attia does about 10 exercises to get ready to deadlift, which takes about 10-15 minutes. He realized that you can deadlift in a way that puts your spine under traction, which is counterintuitive. When you learn the right positioning, you can deadlift and actively create traction in the spine. This is why the deadlift is the most important thing Peter does before he gets on an airplane.

title: The Importance of Zone 2 Aerobic Training
content: Peter Attia spends 3-4 hours per week training in zone 2 and thinks it’s incredibly important for all of his patients. He realized he needed to reincorporate zone 2 training into his exercise program. Zone 2 training has metabolic benefits, improvement of mitochondrial function, health, and density, and increased release of neurotrophic factors. We can do zone 2 our entire lives; we can do it safely, and it yields enormous dividends.

title: Effective Ways to Engage in Zone 2 Exercise
content: Peter Attia likes the bicycle because it has a clear metric that he can adjust - the wattage. Watts are easy to track. He uses an ergometer; he puts his road bike on a device called a Wahoo KICKR which is hooked up to a computer where he sets the numbers of watts he wants and it adjusts the resistance.

title: Devices for Zone 2 Training
content: Other devices can be good for zone 2 training. His wife likes to ride a Peloton (he doesn’t like it); she doesn’t got into a class but sets the resistance and the RPM she puts in, and it spits out a wattage. She also likes a rowing machine. Someone who has good form can get a good zone 2 workout on a rowing machine. Cycling is second nature for Peter; it’s a very efficient thing for him to do. He’s not fond of ellipticals because it’s hard to stay in the proper zone. Treadmills are also a great way to do this. He advises patients to do brisk, incline walking.

title: Measuring Zone 2
content: How do you know you’re in zone 2? Track power output (watts), heart rate, and lactate. Peter has noticed his heart rate will be elevated if he’s sick, dehydrated, or something. In this case back off; adjust the wattage down a bit.

title: Zone 5 Training and VO2 Max
content: Another pillar of Peter’s framework of exercise focuses on the upper end of aerobic, verging on anaerobic exercise (zone 5 training). People often spend too little or too much time in zone 5. This discussion will help you determine what that sweet-spot is. If you are training to be a kick ass 90-year-old, then you don’t need to spend as much time in zone 5 as you might think. What is Peter’s approach to zone 5 training and other anaerobic training protocols? Peter mostly uses the stairmaster for his zone 5 training. He does 1 zone 5 workout a week‒ 3 minutes of zone 2, 1 minute at VO2 max (this is quite difficult to keep this up for 1 minute). Repeat this 4-minute pattern for 20-30 minutes. He does this on the tail-end of a zone 2 workout; so this is his longer aerobic day. When he’s outdoors on his bike, he likes to do a training-type/ VO2 max ride. 4 minutes at 125% FTP (functional threshold power), followed by 4 minutes of recovery.

title: Zone 5 vs Zone 2
content: Peter believes that most people spend too much time in zone 5 and not enough time in zone 2.

title: Peter's Stairmaster Machine
content: Peter uses a fancy Stairmaster machine that has a series of steps that rotate. The higher the intensity, the less resistance it provides. At 8 METS he steps quite slowly, and at 20 METS, it feels like there is no resistance and he’s running up the steps.

title: Limits of Human Performance
content: Alex Hutchinson writes that the limits of human performance in terms of going all out is about 10 seconds. By the time Usain Bolt is running the 200 m, he is slowing down in the second half of the race.

title: Tabata Exercise
content: Peter likes to use an Airbike for Tabata exercise. The 20:10 Tabata is favored because this is the one that was studied by Irisawa and Tabata. Published in BMC in 2019, Tabata training is one of the most energetically effective high-intensity intermittent training methods.

title: VO2 Max
content: VO2 max is like the size of your engine. It tells you how quickly you can take oxygen from the air, into your lungs, get it into your blood, pump it to your muscles, and have your muscles use it in the metabolic processes that provide energy to move you. VO2 max was first discussed/measured in the 1920s by a guy named A.V. Hill, a very good runner himself.

title: VO2 max and weight
content: For comparing to yourself, to see if you’ve increased your VO2 max, it doesn’t matter what you’re dividing by. This is reported as milliliters of oxygen per minute per kilogram of body weight. For Alex, 5 L/ min works out to 80 mL/min∙kg. For Peter who also measured at around 5L/min, he is heavier so this worked out to around 70 mL/min∙kg. You could argue that you should divide by lean mass not total body weight to account for skeletal tissue, fat, etc. as the amount of these tissues can vary but they doesn’t use more oxygen during exercise.

title: VO2 max and limitations
content: The cause of this plateau could be in the lungs, in the heart, in the circulation, or in the muscle’s ability to extract oxygen from the bloodstream and make use of it metabolically in the mitochondria. This is controversial and limitations can arise in any part of this cascade. Conventional wisdom is that the lungs are not the limitation, you can always breathe enough in and they don’t respond to training because they’re overbuilt. But a review was published arguing that in some cases (such as highly-trained endurance athletes), the lungs aren’t overbuilt and can be a limitation on VO2 max. There is also the situation where an athlete is so fit, their heart pumps blood so quickly past their lungs, that it doesn’t have time to fully stock-up on oxygen. This results in exercise-induced arterial hypoxemia. This is usually an issue at altitude. About half of endurance athletes experience this at sea level. There is debate on this because there isn’t any 1 single answer; limits of VO2 max can occur anywhere along the cascade of taking oxygen in and the muscle using it in the production of energy.

title: VO2 max and motivation
content: The nice thing about VO2 max (and why scientists like it) is, in theory it’s independent of motivation. The plateau in oxygen intake is a property of their body and not a result of if they’re excited about the study/ exercise. Historical limits of VO2 max‒ what is it that causes VO2 max to plateau? There is a lot of confusion and debate about the limits of VO2 max. If you want to measure endurance by testing how fast someone can run a mile as hard as they can, but there are many factors that can affect this. Motivation, pacing, lots of factors.

title: Altitude and Exercise
content: Less oxygen is available at altitude and funny things happen. You would think that the first thing to happen is, you would go anaerobic sooner and produce more lactate; but the opposite happens. This is called the lactate paradox. If you exercise to exhaustion at lower levels of altitude, you produce less lactate than you would a sea level. There’s debate over what causes this and if it’s a real thing.

title: Stability in Exercise
content: Stability is the cornerstone upon which your strength is delivered, your aerobic performance is delivered, and your anaerobic performance is delivered.  And it’s the way that you do so safely. Stability is the way that we transmit force from the body to the outside world. In the safest manner possible. Across the muscles which are designed to carry that load. This is opposed to seeing the dissipation of force across joints that are not fit to do so. Stability is the foundation upon which all exercise should be done.

title: Importance of Practicing Stability
content: The correct patterns of movement are characterized by the ability to: 1 – Get air fully into your lungs. 2 – Get your diaphragm low into your abdomen. 3 – Flatten out your pelvic floor. 4 – Generate concentric, robust, intra abdominal pressure that stabilizes every aspect of them. Postural restoration (PRI), DNS, and pilates are all different ways one can learn these principles of stability.

title: Cardio Days
content: Peter does 45 minutes of zone 2 training on Tuesday, Thursday, Sunday. On Saturday, he either does a zone 2 workout (45”) followed by zone 5 workout (30”) or a longer bike ride, more of an anaerobic workout.

title: Weightlifting Days
content: Peter does lower body on Mondays and Fridays, and he does upper body on Wednesdays and Sundays. He always lifts AFTER doing cardio because the reverse has been shown to erode strength-training gains.

title: Missed Day
content: If Peter misses a day, he will never compromise a lift; he will always get 4 lifts in per week. Sometimes it means moving the days around or doubling-up on another day.

title: Exercise Time
content: Peter exercises in the morning once the kids are out the door, off to school on Monday – Friday. The weekends are more flexible.
